content: The Act may be cited as the "Caribbean Coral Reef Protection Act" and includes a statement of policy. The "Caribbean Coral Reef Protection Act" aims to deny Cuba the financial resources to engage in activities that threaten US national security, Florida's marine environment, the environment off Cuba's coast, and the dictatorship that oppresses. The "Caribbean Coral Reef Protection Act" aims to prevent Cuba from accessing funds for activities that threaten US national security, Florida's marine environment, and the dictatorship oppressing the Cuban people. It also aims to deter foreign investments that could enhance Cuba's ability to develop its petroleum resources. The Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 is amended to exclude aliens who contribute to Cuba's development of petroleum resources off its coast. The Secretary of State and Homeland Security will deny visas and exclude aliens who invest over $1,000,000 in entities enhancing Cuba's government. The Secretary of State may waive visa denial for individuals aiding Cuba's petroleum development if deemed necessary for critical medical reasons. The United States may admit individuals for critical medical reasons or litigation purposes under specific conditions. Definitions in this section include the Cuban Communist Party as an agent. The term 'develop' in relation to petroleum resources involves exploration, extraction, refining, or transportation. 'Investment' refers to activities undertaken through agreements with the Government of Cuba or nongovernmental entities in Cuba after January 10, 2005. The entry into contracts for developing petroleum resources in submerged lands off Cuba's coast, purchasing ownership shares in such developments, or participating in royalties, earnings, or profits. The amendment allows for participation in royalties, earnings, or profits in petroleum resource development contracts, as well as the sale or purchase of goods, services, or technology related to such development. The amendment allows for participation in royalties, earnings, or profits in petroleum resource development contracts, as well as the sale or purchase of goods, services, or technology related to such development. It includes petroleum and natural gas resources, petroleum by-products, and liquefied natural gas. The amendment applies to aliens seeking admission to the United States on or after the enactment of this Act. The amendment imposes sanctions and prohibits the facilitation of Cuba's petroleum resources development. The President may impose sanctions on a person who has made investments over $1,000,000 contributing to Cuba's petroleum development or trafficked in confiscated US property. The President can impose sanctions on individuals who invest over $1,000,000 in Cuba's petroleum development or traffic in confiscated US property. Sanctions may include prohibiting loans, guarantees, and export licenses from US agencies. Export sanction prohibits the issuance of specific licenses for exporting goods or technology to sanctioned individuals under various acts. Financial institutions are also prohibited from certain activities. Export sanctions restrict the export or reexport of goods or services. Financial institutions may face prohibitions, such as being designated as a primary dealer in United States Government debt instruments. Financial institutions may face sanctions for being designated as a primary dealer in US Government debt or serving as a repository for government funds. Sanctions can include both restrictions, but each is considered a separate sanction. Sanctions imposed on a person shall be treated as one sanction, and the imposition of both sanctions shall be treated as two sanctions. The procurement sanction prohibits the US Government from procuring goods or services from a sanctioned person. Sanctions will terminate if the President certifies compliance with specified requirements. The President can terminate subsection (a) if requirements of the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act are met. It is illegal for US persons to assist Cuba in developing petroleum resources. The Secretary of State must submit reports within 180 days. The Secretary of State must submit reports every 180 days regarding investments exceeding $1,000,000 that contribute to developing petroleum resources in Cuba's submerged lands. The Secretary of State must submit reports every 180 days on investments exceeding $1,000,000 that enhance Cuba's ability to develop petroleum resources in its submerged lands, including details on the investments, investors, proposed investments, and any sanctions imposed as a result. Investments of any amount of money, in conjunction with trafficking in confiscated United States property, that contribute to enhancing Cuba's ability to develop petroleum resources in its submerged lands, including details on values, investors, confiscated property, and sanctions imposed. The Secretary of State, in consultation with other agencies, must provide assessments of the environmental impacts of Cuba's development of petroleum resources to specific congressional committees annually. The Secretary of State must provide annual assessments to specific congressional committees on the environmental impact of Cuba's petroleum resources development on submerged lands off Cuba's coast and Florida's marine environment, using environmental impact statements as a model. The Secretary of State provides annual assessments on the environmental impact of Cuba's petroleum resources development on submerged lands off Cuba's coast and Florida's marine environment, using environmental impact statements as a model. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, terms like "appropriate congressional committees", "confiscated", "person", "property", and "traffics" are defined as per the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity (LIBERTAD) Act of 1996. Additionally, terms like "develop", "investment", and "petroleum resources" are defined as per section 402(c) of the same Act. The terms "agent" and "instrumentality" are also defined within the Act. The terms "resources", "agent", and "instrumentality" are defined in the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity (LIBERTAD) Act of 1996, with the inclusion of the Cuban Communist Party in the definitions.
